Question: What are EC2 instances, and how do they differ from traditional physical servers?
OptionA: EC2 instances are physical servers located in AWS data centers that require manual setup, maintenance, and cannot be scaled or terminated once provisioned
OptionB: EC2 instances are virtual servers in the cloud. They differ from physical servers by: being virtualized (can be created/destroyed instantly), scalable (resize capacity), pay-per-use (no upfront costs), no physical maintenance needed, can be replicated easily across regions/AZs.
OptionC: EC2 instances are database services that provide persistent storage and data management capabilities with automatic backup and replication features
OptionD: EC2 instances are networking services that manage traffic routing and load balancing between on-premises infrastructure and AWS cloud resources
Explanation: EC2 instances are virtual servers in the cloud. They differ from physical servers by: being virtualized (can be created/destroyed instantly), scalable (resize capacity), pay-per-use (no upfront costs), no physical maintenance needed, can be replicated easily across regions/AZs.

Question: What are the different EC2 instance type families, and how do you choose the right instance type for a workload?
OptionA: All EC2 instance types are identical in performance and capabilities, with the only difference being the pricing model and billing structure
OptionB: EC2 Instance Families: General Purpose (m5, t3) - balanced compute/memory/networking; Compute Optimized (c5) - CPU-intensive; Memory Optimized (r5) - large memory; Storage Optimized (i3) - high IOPS; Accelerated Computing (p3, g4) - GPU/FPGA. Choose based on workload: CPU-bound (Compute), memory-bound (Memory), storage I/O (Storage), ML/graphics (Accelerated).
OptionC: Instance families are automatically assigned by AWS based on application type, with no manual selection or configuration options available to users
OptionD: EC2 instance families differ only in geographic region availability, with all families providing identical compute, memory, and storage capabilities regardless of location
Explanation: EC2 Instance Families: General Purpose (m5, t3) - balanced compute/memory/networking; Compute Optimized (c5) - CPU-intensive; Memory Optimized (r5) - large memory; Storage Optimized (i3) - high IOPS; Accelerated Computing (p3, g4) - GPU/FPGA. Choose based on workload: CPU-bound (Compute), memory-bound (Memory), storage I/O (Storage), ML/graphics (Accelerated).

Question: What are the advantages and disadvantages of On-Demand EC2 instances?
OptionA: On-Demand instances require upfront payment and long-term commitments, making them less flexible but more cost-effective for short-term workloads
OptionB: On-Demand Instances: Pay by hour/second with no commitment. Advantages: flexible, no upfront costs, no long-term commitment. Disadvantages: most expensive pricing model, no discounts. Best for: short-term workloads, unpredictable usage, testing, applications that can't be interrupted.
OptionC: On-Demand instances automatically scale based on demand without any manual configuration, providing the most cost-effective pricing model with automatic discounts
OptionD: On-Demand instances can only be used for development and testing environments, with production workloads requiring Reserved Instances or Spot Instances
Explanation: On-Demand Instances: Pay by hour/second with no commitment. Advantages: flexible, no upfront costs, no long-term commitment. Disadvantages: most expensive pricing model, no discounts. Best for: short-term workloads, unpredictable usage, testing, applications that can't be interrupted.

Question: What are the different Reserved Instance types (Standard, Convertible, Scheduled), and when should each be used?
OptionA: Reserved Instances are automatically applied to all EC2 instances and provide uniform discounts regardless of instance type or usage patterns
OptionB: Reserved Instance Types: Standard (up to 75% discount, can't change attributes), Convertible (up to 54% discount, can exchange for different attributes), Scheduled (match capacity to predictable schedules). Use Standard for steady workloads, Convertible for flexibility, Scheduled for predictable schedules.
OptionC: All Reserved Instance types provide identical discounts and flexibility, with the only difference being the payment method and billing frequency options
OptionD: Reserved Instances can only be purchased for a maximum of 6 months and cannot be used for long-term cost optimization strategies
Explanation: Reserved Instance Types: Standard (up to 75% discount, can't change attributes), Convertible (up to 54% discount, can exchange for different attributes), Scheduled (match capacity to predictable schedules). Use Standard for steady workloads, Convertible for flexibility, Scheduled for predictable schedules.

Question: What are the risks and benefits of using EC2 Spot Instances, and what workloads are suitable for them?
OptionA: Spot Instances provide guaranteed availability with automatic failover protection and are ideal for critical production databases and mission-critical applications
OptionB: Spot Instances: Bid for unused EC2 capacity (up to 90% discount). Risks: can be terminated with 2-minute notice when AWS needs capacity. Benefits: very low cost, good for fault-tolerant workloads. Suitable for: batch jobs, data analysis, CI/CD, workloads that can handle interruptions. Not suitable for: databases, critical production apps.
OptionC: Spot Instances offer the same reliability and availability as On-Demand instances but with slightly lower performance and reduced network bandwidth capabilities
OptionD: Spot Instances can only be used for development and testing environments, with production workloads requiring On-Demand or Reserved Instance types
Explanation: Spot Instances: Bid for unused EC2 capacity (up to 90% discount). Risks: can be terminated with 2-minute notice when AWS needs capacity. Benefits: very low cost, good for fault-tolerant workloads. Suitable for: batch jobs, data analysis, CI/CD, workloads that can handle interruptions. Not suitable for: databases, critical production apps.

Question: When would you choose Dedicated Hosts over regular EC2 instances, and what are the cost implications?
OptionA: Dedicated Hosts are automatically assigned to all EC2 instances and provide better performance at no additional cost compared to regular instances
OptionB: Dedicated Hosts: Physical servers dedicated to your use. Choose when: need to use existing server-bound licenses, have compliance requirements, need visibility into socket/core placement. Cost implications: more expensive than regular instances, but can save on licensing costs. Best for: licensing compliance, regulatory requirements.
OptionC: Dedicated Hosts are only available for development environments and cannot be used for production workloads or compliance-sensitive applications
OptionD: Dedicated Hosts provide the same cost structure as regular EC2 instances with identical pricing and billing models regardless of instance type or usage
Explanation: Dedicated Hosts: Physical servers dedicated to your use. Choose when: need to use existing server-bound licenses, have compliance requirements, need visibility into socket/core placement. Cost implications: more expensive than regular instances, but can save on licensing costs. Best for: licensing compliance, regulatory requirements.

Question: How does Elastic Block Store (EBS) differ from Instance Store, and what are the EBS volume types?
OptionA: EBS volumes are ephemeral storage that is physically attached to EC2 instances and provide the highest IOPS performance, while Instance Store provides persistent network-attached storage
OptionB: EBS (Elastic Block Store): Persistent network-attached storage, survives instance termination, can be detached/reattached. EBS Volume Types: gp3 (general purpose, 3000 IOPS baseline), gp2 (general purpose, 3000 IOPS burst), io1/io2 (provisioned IOPS, up to 64,000 IOPS), st1 (throughput optimized HDD), sc1 (cold HDD). Instance Store: Ephemeral, physically attached, data lost on stop/terminate, very high IOPS.
OptionC: EBS and Instance Store are identical storage options with the same performance characteristics, persistence, and pricing models, making them interchangeable
OptionD: EBS volumes can only be used for boot volumes and cannot be attached as additional storage to running EC2 instances
Explanation: EBS (Elastic Block Store): Persistent network-attached storage, survives instance termination, can be detached/reattached. EBS Volume Types: gp3 (general purpose, 3000 IOPS baseline), gp2 (general purpose, 3000 IOPS burst), io1/io2 (provisioned IOPS, up to 64,000 IOPS), st1 (throughput optimized HDD), sc1 (cold HDD). Instance Store: Ephemeral, physically attached, data lost on stop/terminate, very high IOPS.

Question: What are the use cases for Instance Store volumes versus EBS volumes?
OptionA: Instance Store volumes should be used for all persistent data including databases and boot volumes, as they provide better performance and reliability than EBS volumes
OptionB: Instance Store Use Cases: Temporary cache, scratch data, buffer/queue data, temporary files. Advantages: very high IOPS, low latency, free with instance. Disadvantages: data lost on stop/terminate, can't detach/reattach. EBS Use Cases: databases, boot volumes, persistent data, data that needs to survive instance lifecycle.
OptionC: Instance Store and EBS volumes are identical in functionality and can be used interchangeably for all storage use cases without any differences in performance or persistence
OptionD: Instance Store volumes automatically replicate data to multiple Availability Zones, providing better durability than EBS volumes for critical applications
Explanation: Instance Store Use Cases: Temporary cache, scratch data, buffer/queue data, temporary files. Advantages: very high IOPS, low latency, free with instance. Disadvantages: data lost on stop/terminate, can't detach/reattach. EBS Use Cases: databases, boot volumes, persistent data, data that needs to survive instance lifecycle.

Question: How do Security Groups enhance EC2 instance security, and what are the default rules?
OptionA: Security Groups automatically allow all inbound and outbound traffic by default, requiring explicit rules only to restrict specific ports or IP addresses
OptionB: Security Groups: Virtual firewalls controlling inbound/outbound traffic to EC2 instances. Characteristics: Stateful (allow inbound automatically allows corresponding outbound response), operate at instance level, default deny all inbound, default allow all outbound, can reference other security groups. Default rules: all inbound denied, all outbound allowed.
OptionC: Security Groups are stateless firewalls that require separate rules for inbound and outbound traffic, with all traffic denied by default in both directions
OptionD: Security Groups can only be applied at the VPC level and cannot be attached to individual EC2 instances for granular access control
Explanation: Security Groups: Virtual firewalls controlling inbound/outbound traffic to EC2 instances. Characteristics: Stateful (allow inbound automatically allows corresponding outbound response), operate at instance level, default deny all inbound, default allow all outbound, can reference other security groups. Default rules: all inbound denied, all outbound allowed.

Question: What are EC2 Key Pairs, and how do they enable secure access to instances?
OptionA: EC2 Key Pairs are automatically generated by AWS and stored securely in AWS Secrets Manager, requiring no user management or configuration
OptionB: EC2 Key Pairs: Public-private key pairs for secure SSH/RDP access. Public key stored by AWS, private key downloaded (must keep secure). Used for: SSH access to Linux instances, RDP access to Windows instances (can use key pair or password). Best practice: don't share private keys, use different key pairs per environment.
OptionC: Key Pairs are only used for Windows instances and cannot be used for Linux instances, which require password-based authentication only
OptionD: EC2 Key Pairs provide temporary access credentials that expire after 24 hours and must be regenerated regularly for security compliance
Explanation: EC2 Key Pairs: Public-private key pairs for secure SSH/RDP access. Public key stored by AWS, private key downloaded (must keep secure). Used for: SSH access to Linux instances, RDP access to Windows instances (can use key pair or password). Best practice: don't share private keys, use different key pairs per environment.

Question: What is the purpose of Elastic IP Addresses in EC2, and what are the costs associated with them?
OptionA: Elastic IP addresses are automatically assigned to all EC2 instances and provide dynamic IP addresses that change when instances are stopped or restarted
OptionB: Elastic IP Addresses: Static IPv4 addresses for dynamic cloud computing. Purpose: maintain consistent IP when instance stops/starts, remap to different instances quickly. Costs: Free when attached to running instance, charges apply when not attached to any instance or attached to stopped instance. Limit: 5 per region by default.
OptionC: Elastic IP addresses can only be used for load balancers and cannot be associated with individual EC2 instances for static IP addressing
OptionD: Elastic IP addresses are free regardless of usage and provide unlimited static IP addresses per region without any restrictions or charges
Explanation: Elastic IP Addresses: Static IPv4 addresses for dynamic cloud computing. Purpose: maintain consistent IP when instance stops/starts, remap to different instances quickly. Costs: Free when attached to running instance, charges apply when not attached to any instance or attached to stopped instance. Limit: 5 per region by default.

Question: How does User Data work in EC2, and what are common use cases for User Data scripts?
OptionA: User Data scripts run continuously in the background and automatically restart whenever the EC2 instance is rebooted or stopped
OptionB: User Data: Scripts that run once at instance first launch (boot time) with root privileges. Use cases: install software packages, download files from internet, configure applications, set up web servers, automate system configuration. Runs only on first start, not on subsequent reboots unless configured.
OptionC: User Data can only be used to configure network settings and cannot be used to install software or perform system configuration tasks
OptionD: User Data scripts require manual execution after instance launch and cannot be automatically run during the boot process
Explanation: User Data: Scripts that run once at instance first launch (boot time) with root privileges. Use cases: install software packages, download files from internet, configure applications, set up web servers, automate system configuration. Runs only on first start, not on subsequent reboots unless configured.

Question: What information is available through EC2 Instance Metadata, and how do you access it?
OptionA: Instance Metadata is only accessible from outside the instance using AWS CLI or console, and cannot be accessed from within the running instance
OptionB: EC2 Instance Metadata: Information about the instance accessible from within the instance. Access via: http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/ (IMDSv1) or use IMDSv2 (token-based, more secure). Includes: instance ID, instance type, public/private IP, security groups, IAM role credentials, placement info. Used for: application configuration, bootstrap scripts, getting instance details programmatically.
OptionC: Instance Metadata requires special IAM permissions and can only be accessed by users with administrative privileges, not by applications running on the instance
OptionD: Instance Metadata is automatically encrypted and requires decryption keys that are only available through the AWS Console, making programmatic access impossible
Explanation: EC2 Instance Metadata: Information about the instance accessible from within the instance. Access via: http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/ (IMDSv1) or use IMDSv2 (token-based, more secure). Includes: instance ID, instance type, public/private IP, security groups, IAM role credentials, placement info. Used for: application configuration, bootstrap scripts, getting instance details programmatically.

Question: What are the different EC2 Placement Group types, and when should each be used?
OptionA: Placement Groups automatically distribute instances across all regions to ensure maximum geographic diversity and fault tolerance
OptionB: Placement Groups Types: Cluster (low latency, single AZ, risk of simultaneous failure), Spread (maximum isolation, instances on different hardware, multi-AZ, fault tolerance), Partition (rack-level isolation, multiple instances per partition, good for distributed systems). Use Cluster for HPC, Spread for critical apps, Partition for distributed databases.
OptionC: All Placement Group types provide identical performance and fault tolerance characteristics, with the only difference being the naming convention
OptionD: Placement Groups can only be used with On-Demand instances and cannot be applied to Reserved Instances or Spot Instances
Explanation: Placement Groups Types: Cluster (low latency, single AZ, risk of simultaneous failure), Spread (maximum isolation, instances on different hardware, multi-AZ, fault tolerance), Partition (rack-level isolation, multiple instances per partition, good for distributed systems). Use Cluster for HPC, Spread for critical apps, Partition for distributed databases.

Question: How does EC2 Auto Scaling work, and what metrics can trigger scaling events?
OptionA: Auto Scaling requires manual intervention for each scaling action and cannot automatically adjust instance capacity based on metrics or demand
OptionB: EC2 Auto Scaling: Automatically adjusts number of instances based on demand. Works by: monitoring CloudWatch metrics (CPU, memory, custom), scaling policies (target tracking, step scaling, simple scaling), maintaining desired capacity. Triggers: CPU utilization, network traffic, custom metrics, scheduled actions. Scales out (add instances) when load increases, scales in (remove instances) when load decreases.
OptionC: Auto Scaling only works with Reserved Instances and cannot be used with On-Demand or Spot Instances for automatic capacity management
OptionD: Auto Scaling automatically scales all AWS services simultaneously and cannot be configured to scale only specific EC2 instances or application tiers
Explanation: EC2 Auto Scaling: Automatically adjusts number of instances based on demand. Works by: monitoring CloudWatch metrics (CPU, memory, custom), scaling policies (target tracking, step scaling, simple scaling), maintaining desired capacity. Triggers: CPU utilization, network traffic, custom metrics, scheduled actions. Scales out (add instances) when load increases, scales in (remove instances) when load decreases.

Question: Explain the function of Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) and how it works with Auto Scaling.
OptionA: Elastic Load Balancing automatically scales EC2 instances based on traffic patterns and does not require separate Auto Scaling Groups for capacity management
OptionB: Elastic Load Balancing (ELB): Distributes incoming traffic across multiple EC2 instances. Works with Auto Scaling: ELB distributes traffic, Auto Scaling ensures enough instances are running, ELB health checks trigger instance replacement if unhealthy. Benefits: high availability, fault tolerance, automatic failover, improved performance.
OptionC: ELB can only distribute traffic to instances in a single Availability Zone and cannot work with Auto Scaling Groups that span multiple AZs
OptionD: Elastic Load Balancing requires manual configuration of target instances and cannot automatically integrate with Auto Scaling Groups or health check mechanisms
Explanation: Elastic Load Balancing (ELB): Distributes incoming traffic across multiple EC2 instances. Works with Auto Scaling: ELB distributes traffic, Auto Scaling ensures enough instances are running, ELB health checks trigger instance replacement if unhealthy. Benefits: high availability, fault tolerance, automatic failover, improved performance.

Question: What is the purpose of an Amazon Machine Image (AMI), and how do you create custom AMIs?
OptionA: AMIs are automatically generated by AWS for all EC2 instances and cannot be customized or modified by users for specific application requirements
OptionB: AMI (Amazon Machine Image): Pre-configured template containing OS, application server, applications. Purpose: quick instance launches, consistent environments, backup/restore, golden images. Create custom AMI: launch instance, configure it, create image from instance (creates snapshot of EBS volumes). Can share AMIs across accounts or publicly.
OptionC: AMIs can only be created from AWS-provided base images and cannot include custom software installations or application configurations
OptionD: Custom AMIs require approval from AWS support and can only be shared within the same AWS account, preventing cross-account or public sharing
Explanation: AMI (Amazon Machine Image): Pre-configured template containing OS, application server, applications. Purpose: quick instance launches, consistent environments, backup/restore, golden images. Create custom AMI: launch instance, configure it, create image from instance (creates snapshot of EBS volumes). Can share AMIs across accounts or publicly.

Question: What happens during each stage of the EC2 instance lifecycle, and how does billing work for each state?
OptionA: EC2 instances are billed continuously regardless of state, with charges applying even when instances are stopped or terminated
OptionB: EC2 Instance Lifecycle: pending (launching), running (active), stopping (being stopped), stopped (stopped, billing for storage only), shutting-down (being terminated), terminated (deleted, can't be started). Billing: charged while running, only storage charged when stopped, not charged when terminated. Termination protection prevents accidental termination.
OptionC: Instances in stopped state continue to incur full compute charges, making termination the only way to stop billing for unused instances
OptionD: The instance lifecycle stages are purely informational and do not affect billing, with all instances charged at the same rate regardless of their current state
Explanation: EC2 Instance Lifecycle: pending (launching), running (active), stopping (being stopped), stopped (stopped, billing for storage only), shutting-down (being terminated), terminated (deleted, can't be started). Billing: charged while running, only storage charged when stopped, not charged when terminated. Termination protection prevents accidental termination.

Question: What EC2 metrics are available in CloudWatch, and how can you create custom metrics?
OptionA: CloudWatch automatically monitors all EC2 metrics without any configuration, but custom metrics cannot be created or published by users
OptionB: CloudWatch EC2 Metrics: CPUUtilization, NetworkIn/Out, DiskReadOps/WriteOps, StatusCheckFailed, custom metrics. Create custom metrics: publish data using PutMetricData API or CloudWatch agent. Use for: application monitoring, business metrics, detailed performance analysis. Metrics stored for 15 months (15 days at 1-minute granularity).
OptionC: CloudWatch metrics are only available for Reserved Instances and cannot be used to monitor On-Demand or Spot Instances
OptionD: Custom metrics require approval from AWS support and can only be created for Enterprise support plan customers with special licensing agreements
Explanation: CloudWatch EC2 Metrics: CPUUtilization, NetworkIn/Out, DiskReadOps/WriteOps, StatusCheckFailed, custom metrics. Create custom metrics: publish data using PutMetricData API or CloudWatch agent. Use for: application monitoring, business metrics, detailed performance analysis. Metrics stored for 15 months (15 days at 1-minute granularity).

Question: How does EC2 Instance Connect work, and what are its advantages over traditional SSH access?
OptionA: EC2 Instance Connect requires pre-configured SSH keys and provides the same functionality as traditional SSH access with no additional benefits or security improvements
OptionB: EC2 Instance Connect: Browser-based SSH access without SSH keys. How it works: uses temporary SSH keys generated by AWS, accessed via AWS Console, one-time use. Advantages: no need to manage SSH keys, quick access, secure (temporary credentials), works from anywhere with console access. Limitations: requires IAM permissions, only for emergency access, not for regular use.
OptionC: Instance Connect can only be used from specific IP addresses and requires VPN connection to AWS network infrastructure for secure access
OptionD: EC2 Instance Connect provides permanent SSH access credentials that are stored securely and can be reused across multiple sessions without expiration
Explanation: EC2 Instance Connect: Browser-based SSH access without SSH keys. How it works: uses temporary SSH keys generated by AWS, accessed via AWS Console, one-time use. Advantages: no need to manage SSH keys, quick access, secure (temporary credentials), works from anywhere with console access. Limitations: requires IAM permissions, only for emergency access, not for regular use.

Question: What is EC2 Hibernate, and what are its requirements and limitations?
OptionA: EC2 Hibernate automatically saves instance state to S3 and can be used with all instance types and configurations without any special requirements
OptionB: EC2 Hibernate: Preserves in-memory state (RAM) when instance stops. On restart: resumes from exact state (faster than fresh boot). Requirements: instance must support hibernation (certain instance types), root volume must be encrypted, sufficient EBS volume size for RAM. Limitations: not all instance types support it, larger instance families (C5, M5, R5, etc.).
OptionC: Hibernate requires manual state saving and cannot automatically preserve in-memory data when instances are stopped or terminated
OptionD: EC2 Hibernate is only available for Windows instances and cannot be used with Linux-based EC2 instances or custom AMIs
Explanation: EC2 Hibernate: Preserves in-memory state (RAM) when instance stops. On restart: resumes from exact state (faster than fresh boot). Requirements: instance must support hibernation (certain instance types), root volume must be encrypted, sufficient EBS volume size for RAM. Limitations: not all instance types support it, larger instance families (C5, M5, R5, etc.).

Question: How does EC2 Spot Fleet differ from individual Spot Instances, and what are its benefits?
OptionA: Spot Fleet provides guaranteed availability and prevents instance termination, making it suitable for critical production workloads that cannot tolerate interruptions
OptionB: EC2 Spot Fleet: Manages collection of Spot Instances (and optionally On-Demand) to meet capacity needs. Benefits: automatic diversification across instance types and AZs (reduces interruption risk), cost optimization (chooses cheapest combination), maintains target capacity. Difference from single Spot: higher availability, better fault tolerance, automatic rebalancing.
OptionC: Spot Fleet can only use a single instance type and Availability Zone, providing less flexibility than individual Spot Instance management
OptionD: Spot Fleet requires manual capacity management and cannot automatically adjust instance counts or types based on availability or cost optimization
Explanation: EC2 Spot Fleet: Manages collection of Spot Instances (and optionally On-Demand) to meet capacity needs. Benefits: automatic diversification across instance types and AZs (reduces interruption risk), cost optimization (chooses cheapest combination), maintains target capacity. Difference from single Spot: higher availability, better fault tolerance, automatic rebalancing.

Question: What is the difference between EC2 Dedicated Instances and Dedicated Hosts?
OptionA: Dedicated Instances and Dedicated Hosts are identical services with the same capabilities, pricing, and use cases, making them interchangeable
OptionB: Dedicated Instances: Run on hardware dedicated to your account, but you don't control placement. Dedicated Hosts: Physical servers dedicated to you, full control over instance placement, can use existing licenses. Key difference: Dedicated Hosts give you visibility and control over underlying hardware, Dedicated Instances just ensure isolation.
OptionC: Dedicated Instances provide full control over hardware placement and license management, while Dedicated Hosts only ensure account-level isolation
OptionD: Dedicated Hosts are automatically assigned to all EC2 instances and provide better performance at no additional cost compared to regular instances
Explanation: Dedicated Instances: Run on hardware dedicated to your account, but you don't control placement. Dedicated Hosts: Physical servers dedicated to you, full control over instance placement, can use existing licenses. Key difference: Dedicated Hosts give you visibility and control over underlying hardware, Dedicated Instances just ensure isolation.

Question: What are EC2 Launch Templates, and how do they improve upon Launch Configurations?
OptionA: Launch Templates are identical to Launch Configurations with no functional differences, providing the same capabilities for instance configuration management
OptionB: EC2 Launch Templates: Version-controlled templates for instance configurations. Improve upon Launch Configurations by: supporting multiple instance types, versioning (can't modify, must create new version), parameter combinations, better integration with Auto Scaling and Spot Fleet. Launch Configurations are legacy and less flexible.
OptionC: Launch Templates can only be used with On-Demand instances and cannot be applied to Reserved Instances, Spot Instances, or Auto Scaling Groups
OptionD: Launch Templates require manual version management and cannot automatically track changes or maintain configuration history like Launch Configurations
Explanation: EC2 Launch Templates: Version-controlled templates for instance configurations. Improve upon Launch Configurations by: supporting multiple instance types, versioning (can't modify, must create new version), parameter combinations, better integration with Auto Scaling and Spot Fleet. Launch Configurations are legacy and less flexible.

Question: What is EC2 Enhanced Networking, and which instance types support it?
OptionA: Enhanced Networking is automatically enabled for all EC2 instance types and provides uniform network performance across all instance families without configuration
OptionB: EC2 Enhanced Networking: Provides higher network performance using SR-IOV (Single Root I/O Virtualization). Benefits: higher bandwidth (up to 100 Gbps), lower latency, lower jitter, more consistent performance. Support: Most current generation instances (C5, M5, R5, etc.) support it. Requires: HVM virtualization, compatible AMI, VPC required.
OptionC: Enhanced Networking is only available for legacy instance types and cannot be used with current generation instances or VPC-based deployments
OptionD: Enhanced Networking requires special network hardware and can only be enabled for instances in specific Availability Zones with dedicated network infrastructure
Explanation: EC2 Enhanced Networking: Provides higher network performance using SR-IOV (Single Root I/O Virtualization). Benefits: higher bandwidth (up to 100 Gbps), lower latency, lower jitter, more consistent performance. Support: Most current generation instances (C5, M5, R5, etc.) support it. Requires: HVM virtualization, compatible AMI, VPC required.

Question: What are the performance characteristics of Instance Store volumes, and when should they be used?
OptionA: Instance Store volumes provide persistent storage that survives instance termination and should be used for all database and application data requirements
OptionB: Instance Store Volumes: Ephemeral storage physically attached to host. Performance: Very high IOPS (hundreds of thousands), very low latency, no network overhead. Use when: need maximum IOPS, temporary/cache data, can afford data loss. Not suitable for: persistent data, databases (unless replicated), anything that needs to survive instance stop.
OptionC: Instance Store volumes have lower IOPS performance than EBS volumes and should only be used for low-performance storage requirements
OptionD: Instance Store volumes automatically replicate data across multiple Availability Zones, providing better durability than EBS volumes for critical applications
Explanation: Instance Store Volumes: Ephemeral storage physically attached to host. Performance: Very high IOPS (hundreds of thousands), very low latency, no network overhead. Use when: need maximum IOPS, temporary/cache data, can afford data loss. Not suitable for: persistent data, databases (unless replicated), anything that needs to survive instance stop.

Question: How do you enable termination protection for EC2 instances, and what are best practices?
OptionA: Termination protection is automatically enabled for all EC2 instances and cannot be disabled, ensuring maximum protection against accidental deletion
OptionB: Termination Protection: Prevents accidental termination of instances. Enable: EC2 Console → Instance → Actions → Instance Settings → Change Termination Protection. Best practices: Enable for production instances, disable for dev/test, use with critical workloads, combine with backups. Note: Still charged when stopped, must disable protection to terminate.
OptionC: Termination protection can only be enabled for Reserved Instances and cannot be applied to On-Demand or Spot Instances for cost management
OptionD: Termination protection prevents all instance operations including stopping and restarting, requiring complete instance recreation for any configuration changes
Explanation: Termination Protection: Prevents accidental termination of instances. Enable: EC2 Console → Instance → Actions → Instance Settings → Change Termination Protection. Best practices: Enable for production instances, disable for dev/test, use with critical workloads, combine with backups. Note: Still charged when stopped, must disable protection to terminate.

Question: What are the security improvements in IMDSv2 compared to IMDSv1, and why should you use it?
OptionA: IMDSv1 and IMDSv2 provide identical security features with no differences in authentication mechanisms or protection against SSRF attacks
OptionB: IMDSv2 (Instance Metadata Service v2): Enhanced metadata service requiring session authentication tokens. Security improvements: Token-based authentication (prevents SSRF attacks), session tokens (time-limited), PUT request required to get token. IMDSv1: Simple GET requests (vulnerable to SSRF). Use IMDSv2 for: better security, compliance requirements, defense in depth. Can enforce IMDSv2 at launch.
OptionC: IMDSv2 requires manual token management and cannot be automatically configured, making it less secure than IMDSv1 for automated deployments
OptionD: IMDSv2 is only available for instances in specific regions and cannot be used with all EC2 instance types or AMI configurations
Explanation: IMDSv2 (Instance Metadata Service v2): Enhanced metadata service requiring session authentication tokens. Security improvements: Token-based authentication (prevents SSRF attacks), session tokens (time-limited), PUT request required to get token. IMDSv1: Simple GET requests (vulnerable to SSRF). Use IMDSv2 for: better security, compliance requirements, defense in depth. Can enforce IMDSv2 at launch.

Question: How do EC2 Capacity Reservations work, and how do they differ from Reserved Instances?
OptionA: Capacity Reservations provide cost discounts similar to Reserved Instances and guarantee both capacity availability and pricing reductions for long-term commitments
OptionB: EC2 Capacity Reservations: Reserve On-Demand capacity in specific AZ for any duration. Purpose: Ensure capacity is available when needed, guaranteed availability. Difference from Reserved Instances: Capacity Reservations guarantee capacity (not discount), tied to specific AZ, no term commitment, pay On-Demand rates. Reserved Instances provide discounts but don't guarantee capacity.
OptionC: Capacity Reservations can only be used for Spot Instances and cannot be applied to On-Demand instances or Reserved Instance configurations
OptionD: Capacity Reservations automatically apply to all instances in an account and cannot be configured for specific instance types or Availability Zones
Explanation: EC2 Capacity Reservations: Reserve On-Demand capacity in specific AZ for any duration. Purpose: Ensure capacity is available when needed, guaranteed availability. Difference from Reserved Instances: Capacity Reservations guarantee capacity (not discount), tied to specific AZ, no term commitment, pay On-Demand rates. Reserved Instances provide discounts but don't guarantee capacity.

Question: How do you interpret EC2 instance type names, and what does each component indicate?
OptionA: Instance type names are randomly assigned by AWS and do not follow any consistent pattern or naming convention that indicates capabilities or resources
OptionB: EC2 Instance Naming Pattern: family.generation.size (e.g., t3.micro). Family: indicates use case (t=burstable, m=general purpose, c=compute, r=memory, i=storage). Generation: iteration number (higher = newer/better). Size: resource allocation (nano, micro, small, medium, large, xlarge, 2xlarge, etc.). Example: m5.2xlarge = M family, generation 5, 2xlarge size (8 vCPU, 32 GB RAM).
OptionC: Instance type names are based on geographic region and Availability Zone, with the naming convention indicating where the instance is located rather than its capabilities
OptionD: All instance types within the same family provide identical resources regardless of generation or size designation, making the naming convention purely cosmetic
